January 10, 1901.

A VISIT TO ETON COLLEGE.
was a gray day when we first saw Eton ColITlege.
We did not have that bright sunniness

•

which decks the sward with wild flowers and
gives to the whole the joyous warmth of color
generally held as characteristic of a true English
landscape; but the heaviness of the atmosphere
was conducive to quiet contemplation and serious thought, and the external aspect of the
college surroundings inspired regard for the
antiquity of its foundation and the glory of its
achievements.
From the summit of the great tower of Windsor, from which one can see into thirteen counties in clear weather, we looked across the river
and saw a number of men and boys running
about in an open field playing at the English
game offoot-ball. Down in the town we met a
dozen or more of these men. Great, stalwart
fellows they were, their thin running suits, with
golf stockings rolled down below a bare knee,
and their light, vertically striped jackets, devoid
of all padding, marking them in vivid contrast
to the foot-ball warriors on this side of the
water. Though apparently very young, they
nearly all wore moustaches, and their stocky
build and sturdy demeanor as they swung in a
body through the midst of thc town and across
the bridge leading to the college,impressed us as
typifying the physical glory of young English
manhood. Followed by a crowd of admiring
townsboys, they tramped up one of the streets
of the little town and finally disappeared behind
the doors of a wine shop, leaving me with the
sudden recollection that these men had been
clothed in shirts of black and blue, the first time
that I had ever seen or heard of that combination of colors as a college emblem outside of
Johns Hopkins.
All along the street leading up to the college
little shops displayed pictures offoot-ball teams,
and winning eights, and views of college ceremonies and entertainments, together with lots
of little painted jugs and mantel ornaments all

No. 6,

bearing the motto, Floreat Etona, and little
boys in tall hats and round collars and wearing
those same "Eton jackets," that we see sometimes a part of ladies' dresses, looked in at the
windows from time to time as they walked in
groups with their hands in their pockets or
twisting the enormous watch chains which
hung down over their waistcoats.
Passing from the road through an archway
we come to the quadrangle, called the schoolyard, although it is roughly paved with cobblestones and its only ornamentation is a statue of
Henry VI. in the centre. One of the gloomy
doorways around this yard was open, and a
group of students, some wearing gowns, were
passing in very slowly to recitation, nearly every
one taking a last fond look at his page as he
crossed the forbidding threshold. I was overcome with emotion. It was so like home!
Back in the great hall where the meals are
served to the whole school, and in parts of the
upper school, may be seen carved deeply into
the panels or the tops of desks among a perfect
wilderness of letters and ciphers, the initials of
Shelley, and Charles James Fox, and Eton men
guard with pride the memory of Lord Byron's
cricket playing, Gladstone's youthful writings
for the "Etonian," and George Canning's
school boy popularity.
Beyond the cloisters lie the playing fields.
And such an expanse of soft velvet verdure as
would ravish the sight of a Hopkins man!
Think of a beautiful grassy plain finely kept and
trimmed, and stretching away along the river
with space enough for three enclosed gridirons,
while beyond, across the slough road is another
open field large enough fora half dozen more contests! Passing through a stile in the hedge, we
came out upon this second field, where four simultaneous foot-ball games were then in progress among the younger boys. Here was surely
the paradise of the athlete,open air exercise free
and unconfined at a short walk from the college
buildings and in the purest of atmospheres.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
mined to go en masse to a foot-ball game
being played between the Charlestown eleven
and a team from Summit Point. The men then
proceeded to show by their vigorous and welldirected rooting how much they loved the
Charlestown people and admired their team.
This manner of advertising had the desired effect
and the concert hall was well filled.
From Charlestown the Clubs went to Winchester, Va., where they were received by a full
house. Many of.those in the audience were
inclined to be very sparing in their applause, but
after hearing "Dixie," by the Banjo Club, and a
few of Swindell's songs, they became much more
enthusiastic. The reason for this apparent lack
of interest was because two years ago the Hopkins Clubs had given a very poor concert and
the audience feared a repetition. But this year's
concert has entirely changed their opinion of the
Clubs and the audience next year will no doubt
be much larger and more appreciative. Then
followed a dance with refreshments given by the
youth and beauty of Winchester. The next
morning or rather the same morning, for the
dance did not stop till 2 a. in., the men took the
six o'clock train for Hagerstown. The concert
there was also far better than was ever given
before and yill help to increase the audience the
next time the Hopkins Clubs go to Hagerstown.
Immediately after the concert the hall was
cleared and the men enjoyed the last dance of the
Christmas trip. The next morning, December
29, found the Clubs once more on the train
journeying toward home.
The whole trip was a thorough success, and
not a man on the Clubs would have missed it,
no matter if it had cost twice as much.
E. C. H.
THE Board of Trustees has not yet made any
selection of a man to succeed Dr. Gilman in the
presidency of the University. At their regular January meeting on Monday, they reelected Mr. James L. McLane, President; Mr.
Francis A. White, Treasurer, and Mr. Lewis N.
Hopkins, Secretary of the board,and transacted
routine work. President Gilman's official resignation is to be announced on Commemoration
Day, February 22d.

Mr. Frederick Harrison, the well-known
English Philosopher and literary man, who
originated the movement for the celebration of
one-thousandth anniversary of the death of
King Alfred the Great, of which Prof. J. W.
Bright is one of the American Secretaries, has
accepted the invitation of President Gilman to
lecture at the University. He will appear before
the students early in March, and will probably
give from two to four lectures on historical
subjects.
He will speak before the students of Howard
University before coming here, and will later
visit other educational centers of the country.

the beginning of the new term everyWITH
thing starts up with the renewed vigor
born of the holidays of the previous weeks. The
undergraduate mind disburdens itself of about
three-fourths of the knowledge hastily acquired
during the two or three days prior to the examinations, and begins once more to occupy itself
with the more pressing interests of the lounging
room, the slot machine and Walter's tonsorial
clinics in the basement.
Meanwhile a considerable element twangs the
melodious guitar every afternoon in McCoy
Hall,and craves the indulgentfavor of the whole
University on Friday night. Lately returned
from the joys of Western Virginia and the plaudits of the fair, they feel the inspiration of success. A less considerable number, perhaps, has
begun to cast its mental vision along the southern lands where oceans lie close together, and
not long hence will advise a waiting nation
whether or not to make the waters one.
Upon another field the captains urge their men
to struggle for the flying ball, and strain to
reach the distant goal beyond theirfellows. All
this is good, and should be as it is.
The prospect is as good as it ever was for success in every branch of University endeavor.
High scholarship will, of course, maintain itself
without the necessity of any comment. The
Musical Clubs have been tried and have not
been found wanting; the Senate and the House

This is the season, too, for the annual public
lectures, which will be given in McCoy Hall from
time to time during the next two months or
more. This is one of the features of the University year which is of greatest interest to educated people of the city, and should be to the
students here. But strangely this is not the
case. Lecturers from famous centres of learning
in this and foreign lands pass through our midst,
pause for a while and give us of their best
thoughts, and lo, the mind of the averages
student knoweth not that it was so.
The men miss a great deal often by their
neglect of these opportunities. This neglect is
often without any valid excuse. A few,perhaps,
cannot leave duties at or awayfrom the University; but there are some men who would prefer
to sit in the barber shop with nothing to do but
smoke a pipe and watch the victim in the chair
than listen for a few minutes to a lecture
upstairs, which many are perhaps paying a
good price to hear. Every man should have
some acquaintance with at least the names of
the distinguished scholars of the country, and
when one of them comes to our own University,
we should go into the hall, if for no other purpose than to see what he looks like. It is something of profitfrom a college education to be able
to point out an eminent scholar on the street.
The NEWS-LETTER has harped upon this old
string before, but there may he some who have
not heard it, or having heard, have not remembered, or having remembered, have not heeded,
or having heeded, have not profited thereby.
To all these we say:
"Do not delay;
Do not delay; the golden moments fly."

THE NEWS-LETTER.
A LITTLE TALK WITH MARS.

RE-ECHOINGS OF THE MUSICAL
CLUBS TRIP.

the dawn of the twentieth century, the BR-R-R-R-R-ING!!
UPON
scientific world is shaken to its veryfoundaIt was Friday afternoon, and the noise
tions by the report ofProf. Nikola Tesla relative
to his work along astronomical lines. From his
observatory perched upon the top of the mountains of Colorado, comes the startling information that the learned professor has put himself
in communication with the planet Mars! The
nineteenth century has witnessed the birth of
many inventions and discoveries, but lo! the
coming era is to surpass them all.
How our ideas will broaden by -coming into
contact with the minds of the men of Mars, provided they are a people of advanced civilization,
but if, on the other hand, they are benighted
heathens, it will be our plain duty to benevolently assimilate them, and introduce them to
the two great blessings of our advanced civilization—fire water and gunpowder.
Apropos of the present situation, a question
comes up that we find difficult to answer. We
observe that when an astronomer gives out
definite information regarding the neighboring
planets, Mars is always the one chosen. When
an author has exhausted every other topic he
can think of (to say nothing of his readers) he
mixes up a bit of whisky and absinthe, and the
result is a story about Mars. This is manifestly
unjust, for we believe that some of the other
planets should come in for a share of this attention. For instance, Venus, whom we imagine,
would be equally as interesting (if not more so)
than the fiery god of war.
But we anticipate; let us wait a kw weeks
longer and perhaps the next communication
from Tesla will tell us that his invention has
eliminated space and that we may proceed to
become acquainted with the inhabitants of the
surrounding planets.
At times we shall be awakened from our contemplations by the merry tinkle of the planetophone bell, and then—"John, dear, come to the
'phone. Someone in Mars has rung you up."
After all, the universe is a small place.

BALTIMORE CONCERT.
most important Concert of the Johns
THE
Hopkins Musical Clubs will be given in Lehmann's Hall Friday, January 11th, at 8 o'clock.
From present indications and from the success
of the Christmas trip, this will no doubt be one
of the best concerts ever given during the history
of the clubs. The Glee Club pieces have been selected with the greatest care, and the "1901
medley," contains some of the most catchy
music of the year. The Banjo and Mandolin
Clubs have also been most fortunate in choosing
their pieces, and will most assuredly please all
lovers of good, snappy music. Then Mr. Swindell has added several new pieces to his repetoure, so that the audience will no longer have
to applaud in vain for more of his funny songs.
In fact everything points to a most successful
and jolly concert, and everyone who is so unfortunate as to miss it will lose more than is
usually lost by absence from college concerts,for
the Johns Hopkins can now boast that their
musical clubs take the same standing among the
clubs of other colleges that the Johns Hopkins
University does among the leading Universities
of the country.

ATHLETICS.

OWING to the Christmas holidays, work in all
branches of athletics during the past two
weeks came almost to a standstill, but since the
return of the men to their studies, both the
Lacrosse men and the Track and Field squad
are working with renewed vigor.
The outlook for both teams grows more hopeful day by day. Notwithstanding the losses,
already spoken of in the NEWS-LETTER, caused
by graduation, the prospects for winning teams
again this year are very bright.
Among the candidates for the lacrosse team,
several of the men are showing up remarkably
well under the able coaching of Maddren and
Abercrombie, who are doing their best to get the
men in shape for outdoor practice which begins
as soon as spring opens up.
The Track and Field squad numbers about
thirty men, who are being put through a regular
course of preliminary training by Physical
Director Mackdermott, assisted by Capt. Hoffman and Manager Wroth. As yet no "wonders"
have been developed, but it is safe to say that
ere long "Father Bill" will make several
valuable finds among the many new candidates
who will take prizes for "Old Tom Hopkins"
in the Spring games.
Director Mackdermott informs us that he will
have teams ready to enter the coming Baltimore
Athletic Club and the St. Leo's Gymnasium
games, to be held soon,and is confident that the
glorions showing at the Fifth Regiment armory
will he duplicated. Mr. Mackdermott also says
that he is arranging for an indoor meet to be
given this spring under the auspices of the Johns
Hopkins Athletic Association.
annual convention of the Inter-University
THE
Lacrosse League was held at the Hotel St.
Cloud, in New York, on January the 2nd. Hopkist was invited to send delegates, and Messrs.
R.lie Abercrombie and Wm. H. Maddren were
appointed. But owing to other engagements
neither of the new men were able to attend the
convention. However, a letter was written by
our delegates advising certain changes in the
existing rules of the Association. After some

consideration these changes were adopted and
will be used by the Inter-University League during the coming season.
When questioned in regard to what the Black
and Blue would do when the Lacrosse season
opened: Mr. Abercrombie stated that although
the policy had not been fully determined upon
yet, he thought thatthe Hopkins team would be
a sort of "free lance" this year, watching the
developments of the other teams and playing
any good team, irrespective of the League to
which it belongs. This means, then, that Hopkins will not belong to any Association this
spring, although several tempting offers for the
formation of a new League have been made to
our management.
A meeting of the General Athletic Association
of the University will be held this week, at which
the policy of the present Lacrosse management
will be determined.

IA JO ,110
INDOOR MEET AT PHILADELPHIA.
McDermott has recently received
MaANAGER
letter from Mr. Crowherst, secretary of
the intercollegiate and interscholastic indoor
athletic meet which will be held in the Academy
of Music at Philadelphia, Saturday evening,
March 2d. Mr. McDermott says he will enter
the members of our team in all of the events for
which they are eligible, if possible.
We know no reason why our track team
should not take part in this meet and bring
back some prizes for our trophy room. All candidates who are ambitious for the success of the
team, should now put their best foot foremost
in order that we may enter some winners. Our
later successes or failures will depend upon the
amount of earnest work now shown from day
to day. Let every man come out and do his
best.
Further announcement of this meet will be
made later.

I beg you grant to me
O FATE,
That I may look life in the eyes,
Nor drop my own, nor show surprise
At anything it holds for me.
A faith in man which men can't break,—
A double faith in woman-kind—
The easy trust thou ga.v'st the blind—
For here my faith must never shake.
Give me a hope which soars so high
That it mily lead my wand'ring soul
Toward the ever-distant goal;—
My earthly body need not fly.
A charity, so long that I
It 'round my little world may wrap
A thousand times, with over-lap
Enough to knot and fasten by.
And gentleness, and sympathy;
A readiness of heart and hand
Which makes me brother to my land—
Which makes my land a home to me.
A courage such that it will suit
To tide me o'er my life; and when
I'm called by Captain Death, why then,
Will hold me—standing—at salute.

One asking more, for now I see
I've asked for naught but what is nice.
Pray, hold, throw in a dash of vice,
Lest I'd become a Pharisee.

VALUABLE COLLECTION OF
ANTIQUES.

HE Johns Hopkins University is much indebted to Mr. Theodore Marburg, of this
city, for a rare collection of antiquities which he
recently presented.
The collection numbers about ninety pieces,
collected by Col. Warren during his thirteen
years' residence on the Island of Cyprus, and
has been greatly admired bv savants, who
have endeavored to purchase some of the gems
for Cambridge University and the Berlin
Museum.
The collection comprises gold ornaments,rings
and bracelets of Greek, Syrian, Etruscan and
Phoenician workmanship. Hittile, Egyptian
and Grecian Scarabs and cylinders adorned with
curious carvings and inscriptions also Greek
CAmeos and Intaglios.
The most beautiful of all the collection is an
intaglio head of Alexander the Great, cut in
red sard, and supposed to be a likeness from life,
by the Greek intaglio cutter Pergotoles.
The workmanship is superb, Alexander being
represented as an ideal Greek study in art.
Prof. Richter was especially anxious to secure
this gem, but finding this impossible, obtained
an impression from it in wax.
Of special interest to students of archtelogy,
are the ancient Egyption and Hittite cylinders
and scarabs, especially two of the latter, one of
black hemmatite and the other of white quartz,
inscribed with early Cypriot charactes.
They are believed to be entirely unige as nothing
like them is known in any of the European museums.
Prof. Joyce of Cambridge remarked there especial value to investigators. Judging from their
general appearance and inscriptions, he said,
"they could hardly be of a later date than 1200
B. C., which was about the time blind Homer
was singing the songs which were to make his
name immortal."
It is impossible to place a monetary value on
Mr. Marburg's gift, but aside from this we value
it because it bespeaks an interest in our university, and demonstrates that there are some Baltimoreans who evidently have the welfare of old
Hopkins at heart.

January 10, 1901.

A VISIT TO ETON COLLEGE.
was a gray day when we first saw Eton ColITlege.
We did not have that bright sunniness

•

which decks the sward with wild flowers and
gives to the whole the joyous warmth of color
generally held as characteristic of a true English
landscape; but the heaviness of the atmosphere
was conducive to quiet contemplation and serious thought, and the external aspect of the
college surroundings inspired regard for the
antiquity of its foundation and the glory of its
achievements.
From the summit of the great tower of Windsor, from which one can see into thirteen counties in clear weather, we looked across the river
and saw a number of men and boys running
about in an open field playing at the English
game offoot-ball. Down in the town we met a
dozen or more of these men. Great, stalwart
fellows they were, their thin running suits, with
golf stockings rolled down below a bare knee,
and their light, vertically striped jackets, devoid
of all padding, marking them in vivid contrast
to the foot-ball warriors on this side of the
water. Though apparently very young, they
nearly all wore moustaches, and their stocky
build and sturdy demeanor as they swung in a
body through the midst of thc town and across
the bridge leading to the college,impressed us as
typifying the physical glory of young English
manhood. Followed by a crowd of admiring
townsboys, they tramped up one of the streets
of the little town and finally disappeared behind
the doors of a wine shop, leaving me with the
sudden recollection that these men had been
clothed in shirts of black and blue, the first time
that I had ever seen or heard of that combination of colors as a college emblem outside of
Johns Hopkins.
All along the street leading up to the college
little shops displayed pictures offoot-ball teams,
and winning eights, and views of college ceremonies and entertainments, together with lots
of little painted jugs and mantel ornaments all

No. 6,

bearing the motto, Floreat Etona, and little
boys in tall hats and round collars and wearing
those same "Eton jackets," that we see sometimes a part of ladies' dresses, looked in at the
windows from time to time as they walked in
groups with their hands in their pockets or
twisting the enormous watch chains which
hung down over their waistcoats.
Passing from the road through an archway
we come to the quadrangle, called the schoolyard, although it is roughly paved with cobblestones and its only ornamentation is a statue of
Henry VI. in the centre. One of the gloomy
doorways around this yard was open, and a
group of students, some wearing gowns, were
passing in very slowly to recitation, nearly every
one taking a last fond look at his page as he
crossed the forbidding threshold. I was overcome with emotion. It was so like home!
Back in the great hall where the meals are
served to the whole school, and in parts of the
upper school, may be seen carved deeply into
the panels or the tops of desks among a perfect
wilderness of letters and ciphers, the initials of
Shelley, and Charles James Fox, and Eton men
guard with pride the memory of Lord Byron's
cricket playing, Gladstone's youthful writings
for the "Etonian," and George Canning's
school boy popularity.
Beyond the cloisters lie the playing fields.
And such an expanse of soft velvet verdure as
would ravish the sight of a Hopkins man!
Think of a beautiful grassy plain finely kept and
trimmed, and stretching away along the river
with space enough for three enclosed gridirons,
while beyond, across the slough road is another
open field large enough fora half dozen more contests! Passing through a stile in the hedge, we
came out upon this second field, where four simultaneous foot-ball games were then in progress among the younger boys. Here was surely
the paradise of the athlete,open air exercise free
and unconfined at a short walk from the college
buildings and in the purest of atmospheres.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
mined to go en masse to a foot-ball game
being played between the Charlestown eleven
and a team from Summit Point. The men then
proceeded to show by their vigorous and welldirected rooting how much they loved the
Charlestown people and admired their team.
This manner of advertising had the desired effect
and the concert hall was well filled.
From Charlestown the Clubs went to Winchester, Va., where they were received by a full
house. Many of.those in the audience were
inclined to be very sparing in their applause, but
after hearing "Dixie," by the Banjo Club, and a
few of Swindell's songs, they became much more
enthusiastic. The reason for this apparent lack
of interest was because two years ago the Hopkins Clubs had given a very poor concert and
the audience feared a repetition. But this year's
concert has entirely changed their opinion of the
Clubs and the audience next year will no doubt
be much larger and more appreciative. Then
followed a dance with refreshments given by the
youth and beauty of Winchester. The next
morning or rather the same morning, for the
dance did not stop till 2 a. in., the men took the
six o'clock train for Hagerstown. The concert
there was also far better than was ever given
before and yill help to increase the audience the
next time the Hopkins Clubs go to Hagerstown.
Immediately after the concert the hall was
cleared and the men enjoyed the last dance of the
Christmas trip. The next morning, December
29, found the Clubs once more on the train
journeying toward home.
The whole trip was a thorough success, and
not a man on the Clubs would have missed it,
no matter if it had cost twice as much.
E. C. H.
THE Board of Trustees has not yet made any
selection of a man to succeed Dr. Gilman in the
presidency of the University. At their regular January meeting on Monday, they reelected Mr. James L. McLane, President; Mr.
Francis A. White, Treasurer, and Mr. Lewis N.
Hopkins, Secretary of the board,and transacted
routine work. President Gilman's official resignation is to be announced on Commemoration
Day, February 22d.

Mr. Frederick Harrison, the well-known
English Philosopher and literary man, who
originated the movement for the celebration of
one-thousandth anniversary of the death of
King Alfred the Great, of which Prof. J. W.
Bright is one of the American Secretaries, has
accepted the invitation of President Gilman to
lecture at the University. He will appear before
the students early in March, and will probably
give from two to four lectures on historical
subjects.
He will speak before the students of Howard
University before coming here, and will later
visit other educational centers of the country.

the beginning of the new term everyWITH
thing starts up with the renewed vigor
born of the holidays of the previous weeks. The
undergraduate mind disburdens itself of about
three-fourths of the knowledge hastily acquired
during the two or three days prior to the examinations, and begins once more to occupy itself
with the more pressing interests of the lounging
room, the slot machine and Walter's tonsorial
clinics in the basement.
Meanwhile a considerable element twangs the
melodious guitar every afternoon in McCoy
Hall,and craves the indulgentfavor of the whole
University on Friday night. Lately returned
from the joys of Western Virginia and the plaudits of the fair, they feel the inspiration of success. A less considerable number, perhaps, has
begun to cast its mental vision along the southern lands where oceans lie close together, and
not long hence will advise a waiting nation
whether or not to make the waters one.
Upon another field the captains urge their men
to struggle for the flying ball, and strain to
reach the distant goal beyond theirfellows. All
this is good, and should be as it is.
The prospect is as good as it ever was for success in every branch of University endeavor.
High scholarship will, of course, maintain itself
without the necessity of any comment. The
Musical Clubs have been tried and have not
been found wanting; the Senate and the House

This is the season, too, for the annual public
lectures, which will be given in McCoy Hall from
time to time during the next two months or
more. This is one of the features of the University year which is of greatest interest to educated people of the city, and should be to the
students here. But strangely this is not the
case. Lecturers from famous centres of learning
in this and foreign lands pass through our midst,
pause for a while and give us of their best
thoughts, and lo, the mind of the averages
student knoweth not that it was so.
The men miss a great deal often by their
neglect of these opportunities. This neglect is
often without any valid excuse. A few,perhaps,
cannot leave duties at or awayfrom the University; but there are some men who would prefer
to sit in the barber shop with nothing to do but
smoke a pipe and watch the victim in the chair
than listen for a few minutes to a lecture
upstairs, which many are perhaps paying a
good price to hear. Every man should have
some acquaintance with at least the names of
the distinguished scholars of the country, and
when one of them comes to our own University,
we should go into the hall, if for no other purpose than to see what he looks like. It is something of profitfrom a college education to be able
to point out an eminent scholar on the street.
The NEWS-LETTER has harped upon this old
string before, but there may he some who have
not heard it, or having heard, have not remembered, or having remembered, have not heeded,
or having heeded, have not profited thereby.
To all these we say:
"Do not delay;
Do not delay; the golden moments fly."

RE-ECHOINGS OF THE MUSICAL
CLUBS TRIP.

the dawn of the twentieth century, the BR-R-R-R-R-ING!!
UPON
scientific world is shaken to its veryfoundaIt was Friday afternoon, and the noise
tions by the report ofProf. Nikola Tesla relative
to his work along astronomical lines. From his
observatory perched upon the top of the mountains of Colorado, comes the startling information that the learned professor has put himself
in communication with the planet Mars! The
nineteenth century has witnessed the birth of
many inventions and discoveries, but lo! the
coming era is to surpass them all.
How our ideas will broaden by -coming into
contact with the minds of the men of Mars, provided they are a people of advanced civilization,
but if, on the other hand, they are benighted
heathens, it will be our plain duty to benevolently assimilate them, and introduce them to
the two great blessings of our advanced civilization—fire water and gunpowder.
Apropos of the present situation, a question
comes up that we find difficult to answer. We
observe that when an astronomer gives out
definite information regarding the neighboring
planets, Mars is always the one chosen. When
an author has exhausted every other topic he
can think of (to say nothing of his readers) he
mixes up a bit of whisky and absinthe, and the
result is a story about Mars. This is manifestly
unjust, for we believe that some of the other
planets should come in for a share of this attention. For instance, Venus, whom we imagine,
would be equally as interesting (if not more so)
than the fiery god of war.
But we anticipate; let us wait a kw weeks
longer and perhaps the next communication
from Tesla will tell us that his invention has
eliminated space and that we may proceed to
become acquainted with the inhabitants of the
surrounding planets.
At times we shall be awakened from our contemplations by the merry tinkle of the planetophone bell, and then—"John, dear, come to the
'phone. Someone in Mars has rung you up."
After all, the universe is a small place.

rear platform gazing gloomily at the track,rushing away from him a mile a minute. It was the

had joined them. The rest can easily be guessed.
At first the stakes were low,but-in this game
they remained low, and after a half day of
intensely exciting play, Walter found himself
loser-thirteen cents!

BALTIMORE CONCERT.
most important Concert of the Johns
THE
Hopkins Musical Clubs will be given in Lehmann's Hall Friday, January 11th, at 8 o'clock.
From present indications and from the success
of the Christmas trip, this will no doubt be one
of the best concerts ever given during the history
of the clubs. The Glee Club pieces have been selected with the greatest care, and the "1901
medley," contains some of the most catchy
music of the year. The Banjo and Mandolin
Clubs have also been most fortunate in choosing
their pieces, and will most assuredly please all
lovers of good, snappy music. Then Mr. Swindell has added several new pieces to his repetoure, so that the audience will no longer have
to applaud in vain for more of his funny songs.
In fact everything points to a most successful
and jolly concert, and everyone who is so unfortunate as to miss it will lose more than is
usually lost by absence from college concerts,for
the Johns Hopkins can now boast that their
musical clubs take the same standing among the
clubs of other colleges that the Johns Hopkins
University does among the leading Universities
of the country.

ATHLETICS.

OWING to the Christmas holidays, work in all
branches of athletics during the past two
weeks came almost to a standstill, but since the
return of the men to their studies, both the
Lacrosse men and the Track and Field squad
are working with renewed vigor.
The outlook for both teams grows more hopeful day by day. Notwithstanding the losses,
already spoken of in the NEWS-LETTER, caused
by graduation, the prospects for winning teams
again this year are very bright.
Among the candidates for the lacrosse team,
several of the men are showing up remarkably
well under the able coaching of Maddren and
Abercrombie, who are doing their best to get the
men in shape for outdoor practice which begins
as soon as spring opens up.
The Track and Field squad numbers about
thirty men, who are being put through a regular
course of preliminary training by Physical
Director Mackdermott, assisted by Capt. Hoffman and Manager Wroth. As yet no "wonders"
have been developed, but it is safe to say that
ere long "Father Bill" will make several
valuable finds among the many new candidates
who will take prizes for "Old Tom Hopkins"
in the Spring games.
Director Mackdermott informs us that he will
have teams ready to enter the coming Baltimore
Athletic Club and the St. Leo's Gymnasium
games, to be held soon,and is confident that the
glorions showing at the Fifth Regiment armory
will he duplicated. Mr. Mackdermott also says
that he is arranging for an indoor meet to be
given this spring under the auspices of the Johns
Hopkins Athletic Association.
annual convention of the Inter-University
THE
Lacrosse League was held at the Hotel St.
Cloud, in New York, on January the 2nd. Hopkist was invited to send delegates, and Messrs.
R.lie Abercrombie and Wm. H. Maddren were
appointed. But owing to other engagements
neither of the new men were able to attend the
convention. However, a letter was written by
our delegates advising certain changes in the
existing rules of the Association. After some

consideration these changes were adopted and
will be used by the Inter-University League during the coming season.
When questioned in regard to what the Black
and Blue would do when the Lacrosse season
opened: Mr. Abercrombie stated that although
the policy had not been fully determined upon
yet, he thought thatthe Hopkins team would be
a sort of "free lance" this year, watching the
developments of the other teams and playing
any good team, irrespective of the League to
which it belongs. This means, then, that Hopkins will not belong to any Association this
spring, although several tempting offers for the
formation of a new League have been made to
our management.
A meeting of the General Athletic Association
of the University will be held this week, at which
the policy of the present Lacrosse management
will be determined.

INDOOR MEET AT PHILADELPHIA.
McDermott has recently received
MaANAGER
letter from Mr. Crowherst, secretary of
the intercollegiate and interscholastic indoor
athletic meet which will be held in the Academy
of Music at Philadelphia, Saturday evening,
March 2d. Mr. McDermott says he will enter
the members of our team in all of the events for
which they are eligible, if possible.
We know no reason why our track team
should not take part in this meet and bring
back some prizes for our trophy room. All candidates who are ambitious for the success of the
team, should now put their best foot foremost
in order that we may enter some winners. Our
later successes or failures will depend upon the
amount of earnest work now shown from day
to day. Let every man come out and do his
best.
Further announcement of this meet will be
made later.

I beg you grant to me
O FATE,
That I may look life in the eyes,
Nor drop my own, nor show surprise
At anything it holds for me.
A faith in man which men can't break,—
A double faith in woman-kind—
The easy trust thou ga.v'st the blind—
For here my faith must never shake.
Give me a hope which soars so high
That it mily lead my wand'ring soul
Toward the ever-distant goal;—
My earthly body need not fly.
A charity, so long that I
It 'round my little world may wrap
A thousand times, with over-lap
Enough to knot and fasten by.
And gentleness, and sympathy;
A readiness of heart and hand
Which makes me brother to my land—
Which makes my land a home to me.
A courage such that it will suit
To tide me o'er my life; and when
I'm called by Captain Death, why then,
Will hold me—standing—at salute.

I've asked for naught but what is nice.
Pray, hold, throw in a dash of vice,

VALUABLE COLLECTION OF
ANTIQUES.

HE Johns Hopkins University is much indebted to Mr. Theodore Marburg, of this
city, for a rare collection of antiquities which he
recently presented.
The collection numbers about ninety pieces,
collected by Col. Warren during his thirteen
years' residence on the Island of Cyprus, and
has been greatly admired bv savants, who
have endeavored to purchase some of the gems
for Cambridge University and the Berlin
Museum.
The collection comprises gold ornaments,rings
and bracelets of Greek, Syrian, Etruscan and
Phoenician workmanship. Hittile, Egyptian
and Grecian Scarabs and cylinders adorned with
curious carvings and inscriptions also Greek
CAmeos and Intaglios.
The most beautiful of all the collection is an
intaglio head of Alexander the Great, cut in
red sard, and supposed to be a likeness from life,
by the Greek intaglio cutter Pergotoles.
The workmanship is superb, Alexander being
represented as an ideal Greek study in art.
Prof. Richter was especially anxious to secure
this gem, but finding this impossible, obtained
an impression from it in wax.
Of special interest to students of archtelogy,
are the ancient Egyption and Hittite cylinders
and scarabs, especially two of the latter, one of
black hemmatite and the other of white quartz,
inscribed with early Cypriot charactes.
They are believed to be entirely unige as nothing
like them is known in any of the European museums.
Prof. Joyce of Cambridge remarked there especial value to investigators. Judging from their
general appearance and inscriptions, he said,
"they could hardly be of a later date than 1200
B. C., which was about the time blind Homer
was singing the songs which were to make his
name immortal."
It is impossible to place a monetary value on
Mr. Marburg's gift, but aside from this we value
it because it bespeaks an interest in our university, and demonstrates that there are some Baltimoreans who evidently have the welfare of old
Hopkins at heart.
